1. Introduction

Let Rğ‘…R be a commutative Noetherian ring. Recall Serreâ€™s condition (Sâ„“)subscriptğ‘†â„“(S_{\ell}).

Definition 1.1.

A ring Rğ‘…R satisfies Serreâ€™s condition (Sâ„“)subscriptğ‘†â„“(S_{\ell}) if for all ğ”­âˆˆSpecâ¡R,ğ”­Specğ‘…\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R,

For a dğ‘‘d-dimensional ring, being Cohen-Macaulay is equivalent to satisfying (Sd)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘‘(S_{d}). A multitude of authors have examined Serreâ€™s condition, and the popularity of the topic has continued to grow (cf. [DHV16, HTYZN11, MT09, PSFTY14, Ter07, Yan00]). Serreâ€™s condition, like the Cohen-Macaulay condition, ties homological properties to geometric properties. We define a generalization of Serreâ€™s condition, which also links homological properties to geometric properties.

Definition 1.2.

A ring Rğ‘…R satisfies (Sâ„“j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†â„“ğ‘—(S_{\ell}^{j}) property if for all ğ”­âˆˆSpecâ¡R,ğ”­Specğ‘…\mathfrak{p}\in\operatorname{Spec}R,

In this paper, we examine results about (Sâ„“)subscriptğ‘†â„“(S_{\ell}) from a variety of sources in the literature. We prove generalizations for the (Sâ„“j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†â„“ğ‘—(S_{\ell}^{j}) property. The following will be used implicitly in the paper when appropriate.

Proposition 1.3.

Let Ï•:Râ†’S:italic-Ï•â†’ğ‘…ğ‘†\phi:R\rightarrow S be a faithfully flat homomorphism of Noetherian rings. Then if Sğ‘†S satisfies (Sâ„“j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†â„“ğ‘—(S_{\ell}^{j}) then so does Rğ‘…R.

Remark 1.4.

We now describe the organization of the paper.

In Section 444, we consider the Hochster-Huneke graph of Rğ‘…R (denoted by Gâ€‹(R)ğºğ‘…G(R)) where Rğ‘…R is a local ring or a quotient of a polynomial ring and a homogeneous ideal. It is known that a Stanley-Reisner ring satisfies (S2)subscriptğ‘†2(S_{2}) if and only if every localization of Rğ‘…R at a prime has a connected Hochster-Huneke graph [Kum08, Hol18]. We create a generalization of the Hochster-Huneke graph. In Section 555, we expand upon a result of Yanagawa [Yan00] which states that a Stanley-Reisner ring S/Iğ‘†ğ¼S/I satisfies (Sâ„“)subscriptğ‘†â„“(S_{\ell}) if and only if the Alexander dual of Iğ¼I satisfies a specific homological condition. Given a Stanley-Reisner ring Rğ‘…R with simplicial complex Î”Î”\Delta, Reisnerâ€™s criterion provides a method to check the Cohen-Macaulayness of Rğ‘…R by examining the reduced homology groups of Î”Î”\Delta [Rei76]. Terai made an analogous theorem for describing whether Rğ‘…R satisfies (Sâ„“)subscriptğ‘†â„“(S_{\ell}) [Ter07]. In Section 666, we generalize Teraiâ€™s result by giving an equivalent condition for (Sâ„“j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†â„“ğ‘—(S_{\ell}^{j}) using homology of links in the equidimensional case.

In section 777, we examine monomial ideals of polynomial rings over a field. Herzog, Takayama, and Terai [HTT05] proved for a monomial ideal Iğ¼I and a polynomial ring Sğ‘†S, S/Iğ‘†ğ¼S/I being Cohen-Macaulay implies S/Iğ‘†ğ¼S/\sqrt{I} is Cohen-Macaulay. In section 888, we prove a theorem relating iğ‘–i-skeletons of simplicial complexes and the (Sâ„“j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†â„“ğ‘—(S_{\ell}^{j}) property. We discuss iğ‘–i-skeletonsâ€™ importance with respect to depth.

3. Bounds on Cohomological Dimension

Local cohomology is widely important in the fields of commutative algebra and algebraic geometry. The vanishing of local cohomology is subject to deep analysis throughout the fields. One measure of this vanishing is the cohomological dimension. Let Sğ‘†S be a Noetherian local ring and ğ”ğ”\mathfrak{a} be an ideal of Sğ‘†S. The cohomological dimension of ğ”ğ”\mathfrak{a} in Sğ‘†S is:

cd(S,ğ”)=sup{iâˆˆâ„¤â‰¥0|Hğ”i(M)â‰ 0\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})=\sup\{i\in\mathds{Z}_{\geq 0}|H_{\mathfrak{a}}^{i}(M)\neq 0 for some Sğ‘†S-module M}M\}.

The cohomological dimension has been a topic garnering wide interest (cf. [Har68, Ogu73, PS73, HL90, Lyu93, Var13, DT16]). It is known that cdâ¡(S,ğ”)cdğ‘†ğ”\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a}) is less than or equal to dimSdimensionğ‘†\dim S. We desire to improve this bound for special cases. We will take advantage of various existing results to aid in this endeavor. If 0â€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹S/ğ”â‰¥10ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ”10ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 1, then cdâ¡(S,ğ”)â‰¤nâˆ’1cdğ‘†ğ”ğ‘›1\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-1, which is an immediate consequence of the Hartshorne-Lichtenbaum vanishing theorem ([Har68, Theorem 3.1]). From the work of Ogus, we have 0â€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹S/ğ”â‰¥20ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ”20ptS/\mathfrak{a}\geq 2, then cdâ¡(S,ğ”)â‰¤nâˆ’2cdğ‘†ğ”ğ‘›2\operatorname{cd}(S,\mathfrak{a})\leq n-2 (Remark below Corollary 2.11 [Ogu73]).

In [HL90], Huneke and Lyubeznik prodce a theorem which helps construct more of these bounds. In [DT16], the theorem is reinterpreted for convenience of application.

Theorem 3.1 (Huneke-Lyubeznik, see [DT16, Theorem 3.7]).

4. A generalized Hochster-Huneke graph

For this section we consider two kinds of rings, local rings and rings which are a quotient of a polynomial ring and a homogeneous ideal. When we say ring, we shall mean these types of rings unless otherwise noted.

The Hochster-Huneke graph is a graphical representation of the minimal prime ideals of a ring R. This graph is sometimes called the dual graph of Specâ¡RSpecğ‘…\operatorname{Spec}R and has been examined from many perspectives throughout the literature (cf [HH94, BBV17, BV15, Hol18]). The connectivity of the Hochster-Huneke graph and its localizations provides information about algebraic properties of Rğ‘…R. We will consider a generalization of the Hochster-Huneke graph.

Definition 4.1 ([HH94]).

Let Gâ€‹(R)ğºğ‘…G(R) be the graph with Vâ€‹(Gâ€‹(R))={vi=Pi}ğ‘‰ğºğ‘…subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–V(G(R))=\{v_{i}=P_{i}\} where the Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} are the minimal primes of Rğ‘…R, Eâ€‹(Gâ€‹(R))={(vk,vâ„“)|0â€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(ğ”­k+ğ”­â„“)=1}ğ¸ğºğ‘…conditional-setsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£â„“0ğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ”­ğ‘˜subscriptğ”­â„“1E(G(R))=\{(v_{k},v_{\ell})|0pt(\mathfrak{p}_{k}+\mathfrak{p}_{\ell})=1\}. Then Gâ€‹(R)ğºğ‘…G(R) is the Hochster-Huneke graph of Rğ‘…R.

7. Monomial Ideals

In this section, we consider monomial ideals that are not necessarily squarefree. For convenience, we will establish a few conventions. When we consider the depth of a Stanley-Reisner ring, we shall be considering its depth with respect to the unique homogeneous maximal ideal. When we speak of the localized Stanley-Reisner ring of a link, we shall mean the Stanley-Reisner ring of the link localized at its unique homogeneous maximal ideal. Throughout this section, let ğ•‚ğ•‚\mathbb{K} be a field.

One of the most powerful techniques for working with such ideals is polarization. We reproduce the definition of [MT09].

8. Skeletons

In this section, we examine the iğ‘–i-skeletons of simplicial complexes. We begin with the definition.

Definition 8.1.

The simplicial complex Î”(i):={FâˆˆÎ”|dimFâ‰¤i}assignsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘–conditional-setğ¹Î”dimensionğ¹ğ‘–\Delta^{(i)}:=\{F\in\Delta|\dim F\leq i\} is the i-skeleton of Î”Î”\Delta.
